questions.text:
Which of the following is the highest common factor of 'K' and 'M':
Factors of $$K = 3^{3} \times 2^{2}$$
Factors of $$M = 3^{2} \times 2^{3}$$
questions.solution:
$$HCF = 2^{2} \times 3^{2} = 4 \times 9 = 36$$
Hence, option **B** is correct.

questions.text: Least common factors of two numbers whose factors are $$(x^{3} \times y^{5})$$ and $$(x^{2} \times y^{2})$$ respectively.
questions.solution:
$$LCM = x^{3} \times y^{5}$$
Hence, option **A** is correct.

questions.text: Which of the following is false:
options: Product of 18 and 16 is equal to the product of its LCM and HCF
Product of 12, 14 and 20 is equal to the product of their LCM and HCF
HCF cannot be more than LCM
More than one option is false
questions.solution:
**Option B** is incorrect. Product of three numbers is not always equal to the products of their HCF and LCM. The product of three numbers can be equal to the product of their HCF and LCM only when the numbers are prime numbers.
Hence, option **B** is right answer.

questions.text: If the HCF and LCM of 'a' and 22 is 2 and 264 respectively, then find the value of 'a'.
questions.solution:
$$HCF \times LCM = a \times 22$$

$$2 \times 264 = 22a$$

$$a = 24$$
Hence, option **A** is correct.

questions.text: If the product of two numbers is equal to $$(x+22)$$ and LCM is also equal to the product of the numbers, then find the HCF of the two numbers.
questions.solution:
$$HCF \times LCM = \text{Product of two numbers}$$
LCM is also equal to the product of the numbers, in this case HCF is always equal to **1**.
hence, option **A** is correct.

questions.text: LCM of two numbers is $$(3x+3)$$ and HCF of the same two numbers is 8. If the product of the numbers is equal to 384, then find the value of 'x'.
questions.solution:
$$HCF \times LCM = \text{Product of two numbers}$$

$$(3x+3) \times 8 = 384$$

$$3x+3 = 48$$

$$x = 45/3 = 15$$
Hence, option **A** is correct.

questions.text: If the sum of two numbers is 330 and the their HCF is equal to 22, then find which of the following options can be correct value for the two numbers.
questions.solution:
Here, $$a+b = 330/22 = 15$$

$$22a + 22b = 330$$
Here, option **A** is suitable according to the conditions given.

questions.text: Difference between 56 and 72 is equal to A, then find which of the following options can divide A and leaves no remainder.
options: option A and B and c
questions.solution:
Difference of 56 and $$72 = 16$$
Difference of 56 and 72, 56 and 72 are divisible by **8**, **1** and **2**.
hence, option **D** is correct.

questions.text: If 'X' is the highest number which divides 63, 112 and 154, leaves remainder equal to 3, 2, and 4 respectively, then find the value of 'X'.
Which of the given options is the highest number which divides 46, 94 and 158, and leaves same remainder.
questions.solution:
Remainder be R.
HCF of $$(46-R), (94-R)$$ and $$(158-R)$$ is equal to HCF of difference of the numbers.
Differences = **48, 64, 112**.
Hence, HCF is **16** and option **A** is correct.

questions.text: Find the least number which when divided by 20, 22 and 28, then the remainder is equal to 3 in all cases.
questions.solution:
LCM of 20, 22 and $$28 = 1540$$
Required number $$= 1540 + 3 = 1543$$
hence, option **A** is correct.

questions.text: If 'M' is the least number which when divided by 4, 6 and 8, and leaves remainder 2 in each case, then if we divide 'M' by 16, it gives no remainder. Find the value of 'M'.
questions.solution:
LCM of $$4, 6, 8 = 24$$
To make remainder 2 in each case $$= 24 + 2 = 26$$
Multiple of 26 which is completely divisible by 16 is **208**.
Hence, option **A** is correct.

questions.text: Find the least possible number which when divided by 12, 15 and 18 it leaves 1, 4 and 7 as remainders respectively.
questions.solution:
Here the difference between the remainder and divisor is same which is **11**.
So the LCM of 12, 15 and 18 is **180**.
Required number $$= 180 - 11 = 169$$
Hence, option **A** is correct.

questions.text: Find the least possible number which when divided by 17 leaves remainder 3 and when divided by 6 it leaves remainder 2.
questions.solution:
Dividend = D. Quotient of first case 'x' and second case 'y'.
First case: $$D = 17x + 3$$
Second case: $$D = 6y + 2$$

$$17x + 3 = 6y + 2$$

$$(17x + 1) / 6 = y$$
If we take $$x = 1$$, then $$18 / 6 = 3$$, so $$y = 3$$.
hence, $$D = 17 \times 1 + 3 = 20$$
Correct answer is option **A**.

questions.text: If three bells ring in every 3 seconds, 5 seconds and 6 seconds respectively, then find the time after which all the three bells ring together.
questions.solution:
LCM of 3, 5 and $$6 = 30$$ seconds,
hence, option **A** is correct.

questions.text: Find the 18th term of an increasing arithmetic progression whose difference between the two consecutive term is equal to 9. (First term of the progression is 7)
questions.solution:
$$18^{\text{th}} \text{ term} = a + (n - 1)d$$

$$18^{\text{th}} \text{ term} = 7 + (18 - 1)9 = 7 + 153 = 160$$
hence, option **B** is correct.

questions.text: In an arithmetic progression, the first term and last term are 264 and 736 respectively. If there are 30 terms in the progression, then find the sum of all the terms.
questions.solution:
$$\text{Sum of } n \text{ terms} = n(1^{\text{st}} \text{ term} + \text{last term}) / 2$$

$$\text{sum of 30 terms} = 30 \times 1000 / 2 = 15000$$
hence, option **A** is correct.

questions.text: If the sum of 5 terms of an arithmetic progression is $$(x+10)$$ and the 1st term is 2 and the 5th term is $$(x-22)$$, then find the value of 'x'.
questions.solution:
$$\text{Sum of } n \text{ term} = n(1^{\text{st}} \text{ term} + \text{last term}) / 2$$

$$x + 10 = 5 \times (2 + x - 22) / 2$$

$$2x + 20 = 5x - 100$$

$$3x = 120 \Rightarrow x = 40$$
hence, option **A** is correct.

questions.text: If there are $$(x+5)$$ terms in an increasing arithmetic progression and the first term is 3 and last term is 59, then find the value of 'x'. (Difference between the 4th and 5th term is 4)

If the last term of an increasing arithmetic progression is 40 and 1st term of the progression is 10% of the last term, then find the possible value of difference between the 1st term and second term of the progression: (The number of terms in the progression is less than 10)
questions.solution:
$$n^{\text{th}} \text{ term} = a + (n - 1)d$$

$$40 = 4 + (n - 1)d$$
If we take $$n = 7$$

$$40 = 4 + 6d \Rightarrow d = 6$$
Hence, option **A** is correct.
